Problem:
Consider a complex function \\( z(t) = x(t) + iy(t) \\), where \\( x(t) \\) and \\( y(t) \\) represent real functions of time and \\( i \\) is the imaginary unit. We evaluate the impact of the Laplace transformation \\( F(s) = \\mathcal{L}\\{z(t)\\}(s) \\).

If the Laplace transform is applied to \\( z(t) \\) to get \\( F(s) \\), followed by its evolution defined by a complex differential equation without further intervention, will the inverse transformation of \\( F(s) \\) at a later time remain an accurate representation of the original function \\( z(t) \\)?
Explanation: The Laplace transform and its inverse are linear transformations which preserve the original function under linear operations, assuming no singularity or convergence issues. Given the transformation is properly handled, the evolved function after inverse transformation should coincide with the original function evolved by the same differential equation.
